posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
The link to the CAD you provided does not appear to be publicly accessible.

That said, based on the picture while it’s probably not the simplest part, it should be 3D printable with supports if that’s what you’re asking.

In general you want to avoid large overhangs at angles steeper than 45 degrees on 3D printed parts, but it’s still not impossible. I would be curious to see how you were planning to use this part though.

posts.name: Alex Kalinin
posts.cooked: The stem(?) of it looks really complicated to make, but it’s just a loft between a profile on the back of the camera mount plate and one on the base, if that’s what was confusing you.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
I see, so you’re trying to learn how to make this (or something like it) in CAD.

There’s definitely a lot going on this in this part, even ignoring the curved “arm” that connects the two ends, positioning the ends relative to each other is tricky too.

I’m not super familiar with OnShape, but if it’s at all similar to Autodesk Inventor, there’s at least two ways you could potentially go about doing this:

Create one of the ends as a standard extrusion, then using workplanes and offsets, work your way up to the position you want the other end to be relative to the first.

Create each end as a separate part, position them in an assembly (using constraints or even just manually), and then “Derive” a new part from the assembly (which effectively turns an assembly of multiple models into a single model you can edit).

Once you have your two ends positioned where you want them, you’re going to want to connect them using a loft or sweep operation. This involves drawing a line (or rather, a spline in this case) between the two ends in the shape you want your arm to be, and then connecting the ends along that path.

The hardest part of this model is the sweep operation connecting the ends, I would suggest searching for some guides on how to do sweep or loft operations in Onshape.

Personally though, if I was trying to make a part like this, I would try to make it much simpler.

posts.name: Alex Kalinin
posts.cooked: Yeah, I would avoid making the part shaped like that. It would make it an absolute nightmare to 3d print with pretty much anything except for a powder bed printer which are not common. Making it more boxy would be a very good call.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
The only possible reason I could justify this would be if there was some other component you needed to avoid for some reason and literally your only available attachment point was on the other side of it.

Even then though, I still think I would start with something boxy and just cut out a pocket to make space for the thing that needed to be avoided. It does look cool, but sweeps are a pain.

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked: IMO, this is not the type of part you want to learn how to CAD with.  There are several what I would consider advanced techniques going on here and probably several ways of tackling this part. But, if tasked with making this, I would start with each end.  Work on two, perpendicular planes, position the ends relative to where you want them on each plane, then create a spline or a sweep between them. The best way to learn Onshape is by going through the tutorials.  They are pretty good.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Most (if not all) CAD software will allow you to specify a plane on any mathematical definition (i.e. offset from existing plane, three points, axis and a point off axis, tangent to surface through point, etc)

This really is a question for google tbh, or at least let us know what CAD software you are using to help direct

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: A tip for working with Onshape (or any other CAD software, for that matter): if you don’t know how to do something, look it up. They usually have pretty good documentation. Here’s the relevant Onshape page on the construction plane . (I don’t fully understand what you’re trying to do, though, so it could be the case that there’s a better tool for what you’re specifically trying to accomplish.)

posts.name: jwdt najar
posts.cooked: I’m using onshape I’m very good at cading and I looked how to make it and find nothing the problem is that I want to flip the plan at 2 axes ( I want to flip the plan right and top at the same time)

I’ve seen this thread but haven’t quite followed too much. But:

For this specific part in Onshape, using in-context parts as others mentioned is probably easiest to attain your plane. Place your limelight in an assembly, use the drag and rotation tools that come up when clicking on it, rotate it to your desired orientation (often determined by the limelight eyesight cone/pyramid), then fix it in place. Then make an in-context part off of that.

That’s how I made some limelight mounts last year.

Alternatively, if you want to go crazy, you can make some off-angle plane by manually defining 3 points in 3D space. Here’s an example: Onshape .

I included a variable studio so you can copy and mess around with the values to adjust your plane.
